news_header: Finland faces challenges in meeting biodiversity commitments, with only a few countries completing necessary strategies. The country aims to halt nature depletion by 2030 and become nature-positive by 2035, but has missed opportunities to lead in environmental politics.
news_text: Finland is not alone in its challenges regarding the N. Prize, as only 30 out of participating countries have completed their national biodiversity strategies. The Finnish delegation, led by Minister Kai Mykkänen, acknowledges the importance of these strategies, which are currently lacking. Despite setbacks, Finland aims to stop nature depletion by 2030 and achieve a nature-positive status by 2035. The recent Kunming-Montreal Biodiversity Framework aims to protect and restore significant portions of the world's ecosystems by 2030. The upcoming Calin COP16 summit is expected to gather around 15,000 participants, including heads of state and various stakeholders, to discuss crucial funding and strategies for biodiversity conservation.
